facts.text: Genealogy: Aman Singh -> Sujan Singh; Sujan Singh -> Sobhag Singh (paternal uncle of Moti Singh) -> Moti Singh (defendant) and Zalim Singh (father of plaintiff Lakshman Singh).
In 1923, Sujan Singh (aged ~70) anxious to have a boy versed in Vedic lore adopted to his son Moti Singh (~50), whose wife Rup Kanwar (~45) respondent herein.
On February 14, 1923, plaintiff Lakshman Singh brought from father's house to Sujan Singh's house in Ajmer by Hira Lal and left there.
On March 28, 1923, plaintiff admitted as student in Gurukul Kangri; educated there from 1923 to 1936.
On March 19, 1936, after completing studies, plaintiff returned to Moti Singh's house but not accorded treatment of adopted son.
Plaintiff filed Civil Suit No. 48 of 1944 against Moti Singh for declaration of status as adopted son.
Moti Singh's written statement denied adoption and pleaded limitation.
Subordinate Judge, First Class, Ajmer held plaintiff adopted and suit not barred by limitation.
District Judge, Ajmer on appeal: no adoption, no giving and taking ceremony, but suit within time; reversed Sub Judge.
Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer on second appeal: accepted District Judge findings, dismissed appeal (judgment dated October 27, 1953).
Plaint lacked particulars of adoption date or ceremony; only mentioned document dated June 2, 1926 by Sujan Singh announcing plaintiff as heir post-adoption.
On October 24, 1942, trial court directed further particulars; plaintiff amended alleging adoption between February 13-23, 1923; later specified February 14, 1923.
Ex. P/1 (Oct 21, 1922): Sujan Singh letter to Zalim Singh about sending Lakshman to Gurukul, Moti Singh as guardian.
Ex. P/2 (Jan 31, 1923): Moti Singh postcard to Zalim Singh to send boy for Gurukul admission Feb 20; no coconut ceremony yet; 'educated at Gurukul with a view to adopt'.
Ex. P/3 (Feb 9, 1923): Moti Singh to Zalim Singh urging to send boy for Gurukul selection Feb 28.
Ex. P/4: Gurukul agreement describes plaintiff as grandson of Sujan Singh.
Ex. P/5: Undated admission application by natural father.
Ex. P/26: Sujan Singh will describes plaintiff as 'kept for past 3-1/4 years', son of Zalim Singh, not as adopted.
Plaintiff's letter to father May 19, 1934: No actual adoption yet; if Moti Singh does not desire, he does not wish to be adopted.
Oral evidence of PW2 (maternal uncle): Sent with Hira Lal to hand over to Moti Singh; no knowledge of coconuts or date.
PW7: Hira Lal brought boy, told Moti Singh as desired; Moti kept him.
Plaintiff PW10: Hira Lal told Moti Singh 'come to give in adoption'; arrived ~10am Feb 14, 1923.
Hira Lal DW4: Brought boy to Sujan/Moti house for Gurukul; Zalim said hand over for Gurukul, not adoption; Moti placed hand on head, said 'you have come'.
Ex. D/4 (Sep 6, 1938): Zalim Singh pamphlet claims Hira Lal gave boy on his behalf; first mention of delegation.
Moti Singh died; Rup Kanwar brought on record as respondent.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was a valid adoption of plaintiff by Moti Singh, specifically whether the ceremony of giving and taking took place, including via delegation to Hira Lal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Hira Lal's bringing of boy at instance of natural father to Sujan Singh's house, and Moti Singh receiving by putting hand on head, sufficient compliance with giving and taking.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Law doctrine of giving and taking; delegation possible

petitioner_arguments.text: Natural father can delegate physical act of handing over to third party.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Precedents allowing delegation under unavoidable circumstances

respondent_arguments.text: No factum of adoption; no ceremony of giving and taking; suit barred by limitation (though not upheld).

court_reasoning.text: Documentary evidence (Ex P1-P5, P26, plaintiff's 1934 letter) shows intention to adopt post-Gurukul admission/education, but no actual ceremony on Feb 14, 1923.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No ceremony; boy sent for Gurukul, not adoption

court_reasoning.text: Oral evidence consistent: Hira Lal brought boy for Gurukul; no delegation for adoption; accepted Hira Lal's evidence as natural and impartial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere reception not as adopted son

court_reasoning.text: Hindu Law requires actual/symbolical delivery via formal ceremony of giving and taking for publicity; delegation only under unavoidable circumstances after volition to adopt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No settled intention on Feb 14; no delegation; Ex D/4 self-serving

court_reasoning.text: No custom pleaded/sustained; precedents confirm essentiality of ceremony.

holdings.text: No valid adoption without ceremony of giving and taking; delegation requires prior volition and unavoidable circumstances, neither present here.

precedents_cited.relevance: Formal giving and taking essential even for Sudras; no adoption by deed alone

precedents_cited.case_name: Krishna Rao v. Sundara Siva Rao
precedents_cited.relevance: Formal ceremony of giving and taking essential
Delegation of physical act allowed if volition present, for publicity
Delegation extends to adoptive parent receiving
Registration with presence and questions proved giving/taking in those circumstances; not mere questions

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Law
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires ceremony of giving and taking for valid adoption; delegation under exigencies

outcome.summary: Supreme Court agrees with Judicial Commissioner and District Judge that no valid adoption took place due to absence of giving and taking ceremony; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "The ceremonies of giving and taking are absolutely necessary in all cases... actual delivery... formal ceremony being essential."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Restates core Hindu Law requirement for adoption

key_quotes.text: "There cannot be a valid adoption unless the adoptive boy is transferred from one family to another and that can be done only by the ceremony of giving and taking."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "After qualifying from Gurukul, he will of course remain. He is being educated at Gurukul with a view to adopt."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Ex P/2, shows intention future, not actual adoption
